title: 113_hr1929
content: The Act may be cited as the "Enhancing Employment and Training Through Education Act of 2013" and includes pilot projects to reduce dependency and increase work effort in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. Section 17 of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include pilot projects aimed at increasing work effort and reducing dependency in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. The projects will focus on identifying best practices for employment and training programs to help participants secure unsubsidized employment, increase earned income, and decrease reliance on public assistance. Selection criteria for pilot projects will include enhancing existing programs in the State and agreeing to participate in evaluations of participants' employment activities. The pilot projects under the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 aim to increase work effort and reduce dependency in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. Criteria for selecting projects include collaboration with State workforce boards, replicability, targeting various populations, and inclusion of different employment and training programs. The pilot projects under the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 aim to increase work effort and reduce dependency in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. Criteria for selecting projects include skills development, post-employment support services, and education leading to recognized credentials. Projects are located in various geographic areas and include participants exempt and not exempt under specific sections. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation to measure the impact of the pilot projects on the target population's ability to find and maintain employment. The pilot projects aim to increase work effort and reduce dependency in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress by September 30, 2017, detailing the results, costs, dissemination of findings, and steps to incorporate successful components into future projects. The Secretary will allocate $10,000,000 annually from 2014 to 2016 for pilot projects aimed at increasing employment and earnings in State training programs. The funds are designated for project costs, administration, data provision, and independent evaluation. Non-Federal funds cannot be replaced by these funds. The $10,000,000 allocated annually from 2014 to 2016 for pilot projects to increase employment and earnings in State training programs may not replace non-Federal funds used for existing employment and training activities.
